overview: Seeka Limited is New Zealand's largest kiwifruit post-harvest operator, providing integrated orcharding, post-harvest (packing and coolstorage), and retail services to the fresh produce industry. The company services approximately 2,800 growers, handles about 20% of the national kiwifruit crop, and supplies global marketer Zespri along with retail customers in Australia, Asia, and New Zealand. Seeka also operates growing and packing facilities in Victoria, Australia, where it is the largest kiwifruit producer.

businessModel.description: Seeka operates an integrated horticultural services business model spanning the entire kiwifruit supply chain from orchard to market. Revenue is generated through service fees per unit handled (packing and coolstorage), orchard management fees, profit sharing on leased orchards, and direct fruit sales. The business benefits from fixed infrastructure and variable labor costs, with profitability highly sensitive to kiwifruit volumes.

revenueStreams.description: Grading and packing service fees per tray, coolstorage and loadout fees. Packed 43.0 million class 1 kiwifruit trays in FY2024, up 44% from FY2023. Also packs avocado, citrus, and persimmon on contract.
revenueStreams.margins: High - EBITDA margin of 34.3% in FY2024

revenueStreams.description: Management fees from managed orchards (12.7m trays) and profit share from leased orchards (4.6m trays). Produced 17.3 million class 1 trays of kiwifruit in FY2024.
revenueStreams.margins: Moderate - EBITDA margin of 6.0% in FY2024

revenueStreams.description: Sales commissions on avocado, Kiwiberry, Class 2 kiwifruit; service fees for imported tropical fruits; wholesale market operations; production of Kiwi Crush and avocado oil.
revenueStreams.margins: Moderate - EBITDA margin of 8.4% in FY2024

revenueStreams.description: Production and sale of kiwifruit (2.3m kg, up 166%), nashi pears, and jujube from owned and leased Victorian orchards. Direct marketing to Australian and Asian markets.
revenueStreams.margins: Good - EBITDA margin of 16.7% in FY2024

businessModel.customerBase: B2B primarily - supplies Zespri (dominant customer for kiwifruit), third-party marketers for citrus/persimmon, and direct retail customers in Australia and Asia. Services approximately 2,800 kiwifruit growers.

newZealand.regions: Northland, Coromandel, Bay of Plenty (85% of kiwifruit sourced), Opotiki, Gisborne, Hawke's Bay

businessModel.seasonality: Highly seasonal - kiwifruit harvest and packing occurs March to July, with peak activity April-June. Coolstorage operations extend through October. Australian kiwifruit harvest is January-March. SeekaFresh operates year-round with imported tropical fruits.

competitivePosition.marketPosition: Market leader in NZ kiwifruit post-harvest with approximately 20% national market share. Largest kiwifruit producer in Australasia. Operates 12 packing facilities with 16 graders and extensive coolstorage network across key growing regions.

mainCompetitors.name: EastPack
mainCompetitors.description: Main post-harvest competitor in Bay of Plenty region

mainCompetitors.name: Mount Pack & Cool (MPac)
mainCompetitors.description: Most highly automated kiwifruit processing plant globally, packing 30m trays

mainCompetitors.name: Other regional post-harvest operators
mainCompetitors.description: Approximately 39 packing facilities total in NZ industry, including smaller regional players

moatFactors.description: 12 facilities across all major growing regions from Northland to Gisborne provides geographic diversification, reduces weather risk, and creates high barriers to entry due to capital intensity ($388.3m in PP&E). Capacity for 50+ million trays with current utilization at 43m trays provides growth runway without major capex.

Services 2,800 growers with multi-year contracts. Growers face high switching costs due to harvest timing coordination, pre-season commitments, and integrated orchard management services. Seeka achieved high pre-season grower signups for 2025.

KKP automated packing line (2nd season) and upgrades at Oakside and Gisborne deliver cost advantages. New highly-automated Kerikeri facility commissioning in 2025. Expenses per tray down 19% in FY2024 despite higher labor costs. However, competitors like MPac have superior automation.

End-to-end services from orchard management through post-harvest to retail creates stickiness and captures more value chain. SeekaFresh diversifies beyond Zespri dependency. Australian operations provide counter-seasonal production.

Seeka Risk Management Limited provides direct access to international insurance markets, delivering material cost savings and avoiding inflationary increases in premiums - competitive advantage in high-risk cyclone regions.

competitiveWeaknesses: Capital intensity limits financial flexibility - $137.3m net debt at end FY2024 (down from $172.4m)
Automation lags best-in-class competitors like MPac which processes 600k fruit/hour
Concentrated customer base - heavy reliance on Zespri as primary customer for kiwifruit (60% of revenue)
Exposure to weather events in key regions - Cyclone Gabrielle impact in 2023 demonstrated vulnerability
Fixed cost base creates operational leverage - profitability highly sensitive to volume fluctuations

growthDrivers.description: Zespri forecasting record 2025/26 season with 205-215 million trays (up from ~190m in 2024/25). Industry targeting 190m trays by 2027, growing to 28,397 seasonal workers by 2031. Seeka's 50m+ tray capacity can absorb growth without major capex. Additional 400 hectares of SunGold license being released in 2026.

growthDrivers.driver: Market share gains from industry consolidation
growthDrivers.description: History of successful acquisitions (OPAC, Aongatete, Orangewood, NZ Fruits). Industry consolidating from ~39 packing facilities. Seeka well-positioned to acquire smaller regional operators as capital requirements increase with automation needs.

New highly-automated Kerikeri packline commissioning 2025 incorporating latest technology. Cost per tray declining with automation - down 19% in FY2024. Labor constraints easing but automation reduces reliance on seasonal workers and improves margins.

$17.2m invested in new orchard development including 64 hectares of kiwifruit plus new pear varieties and jujube expansion. Australian kiwifruit production up 166% in FY2024 to 2.3m kg with new Psa crop protection program. New orchards entering production from 2026. Partnership with Warakirri Asset Management opens development opportunities. Australia accounts for 70% of Australian kiwifruit production.

Contract packing of citrus (14.0m kg) and persimmon (1.5m kg) growing, improving asset utilization. Avocado operations (1,780 tonnes grown plus third-party packing). Tropical fruit imports and wholesale market through SeekaFresh. Kiwi Crush and avocado oil value-added products.

65 hectares under development with long-term supply commitments. $7.1m invested in 15 hectares kiwifruit and 13 hectares avocado on long-term leased land. Orcharding EBITDA improving as orchards reach maturity. Seeka's managed portfolio producing 12.7m trays with leased portfolio at 4.6m trays (up from 2.7m in FY2023).

business.description: ~60% of revenue dependent on Zespri as the single-desk marketer for NZ kiwifruit exports. Any changes to Zespri's structure, market performance, or grower pool allocation would materially impact Seeka. Limited ability to diversify away from this dependency.
business.mitigation: SeekaFresh retail services, Australian operations, and contract packing provide some diversification. Strong grower relationships help maintain supply volumes.

business.risk: Volume volatility from weather and growing conditions
business.description: Profitability highly sensitive to kiwifruit volumes due to fixed cost base. FY2023 volumes of 29.8m trays resulted in $21.0m loss before tax, while FY2024 volumes of 43.0m trays generated $29.7m profit. Weather events (wind, water stress, cyclones) can dramatically impact yields. 2024 saw lingering water stress in Northland, Coromandel, Gisborne, Hawke's Bay despite overall good conditions.
business.mitigation: Geographic diversification across NZ regions. Australian counter-seasonal production. Captive insurance for material damage. Growers switching to rootstocks better suited to wet conditions.

business.description: Psa-V bacterial canker disease remains a specified organism requiring ongoing management. New Psa strains from overseas or mutations in NZ could cause production losses. Australian operations particularly exposed - Seeka implemented new crop protection program that improved 2024 yields but ongoing vigilance required.
business.mitigation: Industry-wide KVH biosecurity management. Seeka's Australian crop protection program has proven effective. Development of resistant cultivars ongoing. Regular testing and monitoring protocols in place.

business.description: Despite improvements (first time in 5 years all shifts fully staffed in 2024), structural labor shortages persist. Projected seasonal workforce needs growing from 19,500 (2019) to 28,397 (2031). Wage inflation and Accredited Employer Work Visa scheme changes could pressure margins.
business.mitigation: Automation strategy reducing labor dependency. Purpose-built worker accommodation (Turanga Whetu facility). Industry-wide push for automation and robotics.

business.description: Major capex on automation at KKP, Oakside, Gisborne, and new Kerikeri facility. Technology must deliver promised efficiency gains and ROI. Competitors like MPac have more advanced automation (600k fruit/hour processing). Integration challenges and downtime during implementation could impact operations.
business.mitigation: KKP automated line in 2nd year showing incremental improvements. Mix of automated and manual lines provides flexibility for variable fruit quality. Prudent staged rollout approach.

financial.risk: Debt levels and interest rate exposure
financial.description: Net debt of $137.3m at 31-Dec-2024 (down from $172.4m). $17.1m finance expenses in FY2024 reflect high interest rate environment. Despite improvements, leverage remains material relative to $266.4m net assets. Banking covenant compliance restored but limited headroom for adverse volume scenarios.
financial.mitigation: Strong FY2024 cash flow ($66.0m from operating activities) enabling $35.1m debt reduction. Interest rates declining from 2024 peaks - positioned to benefit. Capital investment held to maintenance levels. Available headroom increased to $61.1m from $23.2m.

financial.description: $388.3m in PP&E requires ongoing maintenance capex. Australian expansion ($17.2m invested) and automation upgrades consume cash. Asset sales (Turanga Whetu accommodation, potential sale-leaseback opportunities) below expectations, limiting capital recycling.
financial.mitigation: Current capacity of 50m+ trays can handle near-term industry growth without major capex. Existing automation upgrades improving efficiency and throughput. Dividend restart demonstrates improving cash generation.

financial.description: Operating costs in NZD while grower returns (and indirectly Seeka's service fees) benefit from weak NZD via Zespri's USD/EUR export revenues. Australian operations have AUD exposure. Currency movements can impact relative competitiveness and returns.
financial.mitigation: Natural hedge through revenue linkage to export prices. Zespri forecast notes favorable FX gains supporting grower returns. Relatively minor direct currency exposure.

regulatory.risk: Changes to Zespri single-desk export model
regulatory.description: Zespri operates as regulated single-desk exporter for NZ kiwifruit. Any regulatory changes allowing competing exporters could fragment the industry and impact coordination, quality standards, and potentially grower pool allocations to post-harvest operators.
regulatory.mitigation: Current model has strong industry and government support. Zespri delivering record returns supports status quo. Seeka's scale and quality would remain competitive advantages under alternative models.

regulatory.description: Emissions up to 26,682 tonnes CO2e in FY2024 (up from 17,987 in FY2023) due to higher volumes. Emissions intensity also increased. Future carbon pricing or emission reduction mandates could increase costs, particularly for refrigerant use and electricity for coolstorage.
regulatory.mitigation: Solar installations (220kW added at Kerikeri). Transparency in reporting since 2019 with meaningful reduction targets. Improving coolstore efficiency and refrigerant management. No carbon offsets purchased to date indicates some headroom.

regulatory.description: Export markets have stringent food safety requirements. Traceability, residue testing, and quality standards critical. Non-compliance could result in market access issues or recalls.
regulatory.mitigation: Strong track record - 'excellent offshore quality in 2024' per management. Low onshore fruit loss. Real-time data visualization and Seeka app for tracking. Industry-leading quality control processes.

macro.description: Kiwifruit is premium fresh produce - consumer discretionary category. Economic downturn in key markets (Europe, North America, China) could reduce demand and pricing. However, Zespri 2025/26 forecast indicates strong demand continuing with record returns expected.
macro.mitigation: Kiwifruit has health halo and positioned as affordable premium. Zespri's marketing and brand strength. Diversified global markets. Strong recent demand in Europe and North America per Zespri guidance.

macro.description: Cyclone Gabrielle (2023) demonstrated catastrophic impact potential on both orchards and infrastructure. Climate change increasing frequency/severity of extreme weather events. Northland and Hawke's Bay particularly exposed regions where Seeka operates.
macro.mitigation: Geographic diversification across regions. Captive insurance structure (Seeka Risk Management Ltd) provides cost-effective coverage. Material damage and business interruption insurance in place. Targeted infrastructure investments to mitigate fire risk.

macro.description: While diversifying, Zespri has significant China exposure. Geopolitical tensions, trade restrictions, or economic slowdown in China could impact kiwifruit demand and pricing, flowing through to grower returns and Seeka volumes.
macro.mitigation: Indirect exposure through Zespri. Zespri actively diversifying markets with strong growth in Europe and North America. Seeka's revenue primarily from service fees with limited direct China exposure.

macro.description: Packaging materials, electricity for coolstorage, fuel for transportation, and agricultural inputs subject to commodity price volatility. Labor costs trending upward structurally.
macro.mitigation: Service fee model allows some cost pass-through to growers. Automation reducing labor intensity. Efficiency improvements offsetting cost inflation - cost per tray down 19% despite input inflation.

execution.description: History of multiple acquisitions (OPAC, Aongatete, Orangewood, NZ Fruits). Successfully integrating operations, realizing synergies, and maintaining grower relationships critical. Management bandwidth stretched during integration periods.
execution.mitigation: Experienced management team with successful track record. Currently focused on optimizing existing assets rather than major M&A. 2024 saw no major asset acquisitions.

execution.description: Ashley Waugh resigned from Board 31-Dec-2024 after 10 years. Two new directors appointed (Mark Dewdney 1-Dec-2024, Hayley Gourley 1-Jan-2025). Board continuity and governance during transition important.
execution.mitigation: CEO Michael Franks and Chair Fred Hutchings provide continuity. Orderly succession planning. New directors bring fresh perspectives.

macroFactors.industryOutlook: NZ kiwifruit industry in strong growth phase with Zespri forecasting record 2025/26 season of 205-215 million trays. Global demand robust particularly in Europe and North America. Zespri targeting $4.5bn revenue. Industry expanding with 400 hectares new SunGold license in 2026. Structural growth from health trends and premium fruit consumption. Some risks from market concentration and climate impacts.
macroFactors.cyclicality: Moderately cyclical - exposed to consumer discretionary spending on premium produce, but kiwifruit has health positioning and affordable luxury appeal. Volume volatility from weather creates annual fluctuations but long-term industry growth trajectory stable. Counter-cyclical operational leverage - fixed costs amplify both upturns (FY2024 +$50.7m profit swing on 44% volume increase) and downturns.
macroFactors.interestRateSensitivity: Moderate direct sensitivity - $137.3m net debt with $17.1m finance expenses. Interest rate declines from 2024 peaks will benefit earnings. Indirect sensitivity through consumer spending on premium produce and rural land values affecting orchard development economics.
keyInputCosts: Labor (seasonal workers) - structural shortage driving wage inflation, partially offset by automation
Electricity - coolstorage operations energy-intensive, exposed to NZ electricity market volatility
Packaging materials - cartons, trays, labels subject to commodity price fluctuations
Refrigerants - coolstore operations, also environmental compliance considerations
Fuel - transportation of fruit from orchards to facilities and to ports
macroFactors.climateExposure: High exposure to climate variability and extreme weather events. Water stress, wind damage, and cyclones can dramatically impact yields. Increasing frequency of severe weather from climate change presents ongoing risk. However, geographic diversification, improved rootstocks, Australian operations, and insurance provide some mitigation.

recentDevelopments.event: Record H1 profit after tax of $37.8 million
recentDevelopments.description: Unaudited results for six months ended 30 June 2025 showed NZ kiwifruit volumes of 47.1 million class 1 trays (up from 43.0m pcp). Dividend of $0.15 per share paid 15 October 2025. Full year NPBT forecast increased to $35.0-39.0 million range.
Ashley Waugh resigned 31-Dec-2024 after 10 years. Mark Dewdney appointed 1-Dec-2024, Hayley Gourley appointed 1-Jan-2025. DRP strike price for January 2026 dividend set at $4.5325 per share.
Shareholders approved capital raise of up to $2.59 million with 88% support, strengthening balance sheet for growth initiatives.
Partnership with Warakirri Asset Management's Farmland Fund in Goulburn Valley deal opens opportunities for future sustainable development in Victoria region.

NPBT of $29.7m (up from $21.0m loss in FY2023) on revenue of $411.4m (+37%). Net debt reduced $35.1m to $137.3m. Board declared total 15 cents per share dividend (10c paid Jan 2025, 5c paid Apr 2025) - first dividends since hiatus following Cyclone Gabrielle.

Automation upgrades at Oakside and Gisborne enhanced capacity and throughput. KKP automated line in 2nd season showing incremental improvements. Cost per tray down 19%. New Kerikeri highly-automated packline to commission in 2025.
First time in five years all post-harvest shifts fully staffed across all regions. Easing of labor constraints supported operational excellence and timely harvest for all growers.
$17.2m invested in new orchard developments including 64 hectares kiwifruit. Australian kiwifruit production up 166% to 2.3m kg with new Psa crop protection program. Revenue up 85% to $19.2m.

Zespri forecasting record 2025/26 season with 205-215 million trays and strong per-tray returns for growers. Release of additional 400 hectares SunGold license in 2026. Targeting $4.5bn global revenue.

2024 represented recovery year from 2023's cyclone-impacted low volume season (29.8m trays). Better growing conditions across all regions drove 44% volume increase, though some regions still showed lingering water stress effects.

bullCase.summary: Seeka is a levered play on structural growth in NZ kiwifruit industry, with operational leverage, improving efficiency, and Australian expansion providing multiple growth vectors. Recent results demonstrate powerful earnings recovery potential when volumes normalize.
points: Industry tailwinds: Zespri forecasting record 205-215m tray 2025/26 season with strong grower returns. Long-term industry growth trajectory toward 190m+ trays by 2027. Additional 400 hectares SunGold license releasing in 2026. Global demand robust in Europe and North America. Seeka's 50m+ tray capacity can absorb growth with minimal incremental capex.

Operational leverage drives profit growth: FY2024 demonstrated dramatic earnings power with 44% volume increase driving $50.7m profit swing from $21.0m loss to $29.7m profit. Cost per tray down 19% from automation and efficiency gains. Further operating leverage available as volumes grow toward capacity limits.

Automation delivering competitive advantages: Cost per tray declining despite wage inflation. New Kerikeri highly-automated facility commissioning 2025 will be most advanced in portfolio. Automation reducing labor dependency while competitors face ongoing workforce challenges. Investments at KKP, Oakside, Gisborne showing incremental performance improvements.

Australian growth engine accelerating: Kiwifruit production up 166% with new Psa crop protection program validated. $17.2m invested in 64 hectares new kiwifruit plus pear and jujube expansion. Warakirri partnership opens significant development pipeline. Australia accounts for 70% of Australian kiwifruit production - dominant market position. Counter-seasonal production diversifies risk.

Balance sheet repair enables returns to shareholders: Net debt reduced $35.1m in FY2024 to $137.3m. Banking covenant compliance restored with $61.1m available headroom (vs $23.2m start of 2024). Dividend restart at 15 cents per share for FY2024 with strong coverage. Declining interest rates will benefit $12.3m annual interest expense. Cash generation of $66.0m from operations demonstrates conversion.

Attractive valuation with significant upside: Trading at $4.65 with analyst intrinsic value of $9.27 NZD suggesting 50% undervaluation. Consensus price target of $2.50 appears stale given strong FY2024 and H1-2025 results. Forward dividend yield of 4.3%. Stock up 67.88% over past year but still below 3-year highs despite earnings recovery.

Consolidation opportunity: Industry fragmented with ~39 packing facilities. Seeka has successful M&A track record (OPAC, Aongatete, Orangewood). Increasing capital requirements for automation favor larger operators. Potential to acquire distressed competitors and realize synergies.

bearCase.summary: Seeka remains a high-risk, weather-dependent business with customer concentration, debt burden, and climate change exposure. Profitability entirely dependent on kiwifruit volumes which are outside management control.
points: Volume volatility creates binary outcomes: FY2023's 29.8m trays resulted in $21.0m loss while FY2024's 43.0m trays generated $29.7m profit. Weather, cyclones, disease, or water stress in key Bay of Plenty region (85% of supply) can devastate annual results. Fixed cost base provides no downside protection. Climate change increasing frequency of extreme weather events.

Zespri customer concentration risk: ~60% of revenue dependent on single customer/marketer. No ability to diversify away from Zespri given single-desk export structure. Changes to Zespri pool allocation, service fee structures, or grower relationships could materially impact Seeka. Limited negotiating leverage as service provider to regulated monopoly.

Automation lag versus best-in-class: MPac processes 600k fruit/hour with world's most automated facility packing 30m trays (vs Seeka's 43m across 12 facilities). Seeka's capex investments playing catch-up. Risk that automation advantages erode as competitors invest. New Kerikeri facility is major execution risk - technology integration challenges or underperformance could hurt returns.

Debt overhang limits flexibility: $137.3m net debt (51% of net assets) constrains ability to fund growth investments, weather downturns, or pursue M&A. $17.1m finance expenses consume profits. Despite improvement, banking covenant headroom still limited for adverse scenarios. Australian expansion requiring $17.2m capex competes with debt reduction priority.

Mature industry in small market: NZ kiwifruit is niche global market dominated by Zespri. Limited growth beyond current trajectory. Industry already consolidated with Seeka, EastPack, MPac controlling majority. Market share gains require displacing competitors with comparable capabilities. Dividend policy and capital allocation decisions constrained by debt levels.

Australian execution risk: Material capital committed ($17.2m) to unproven Australian expansion. Kiwifruit production up 166% in FY2024 but from low base (2.3m kg vs 43m trays in NZ). Psa management in Australia critical - disease outbreak could destroy investment. Market development and distribution channels less established than NZ.

Climate and biosecurity existential threats: Psa-V disease required industry restructuring and new varietals. New strain could require another costly transition. Increasing cyclone frequency (Gabrielle 2023) and water stress from climate change threaten long-term viability of current orchard locations. Insurance costs rising while coverage limits tightening.

Regulatory and structural change risk: Potential changes to Zespri single-desk model could fragment industry and reduce coordination efficiencies. Environmental regulations on emissions (26,682 tonnes CO2e) could require costly carbon offsets or operational changes. Food safety incidents could close export markets.

analystConsensus.note: Consensus data appears dated and likely does not reflect strong FY2024 and H1-2025 results. Intrinsic valuation analysis by Alpha Spread suggests significant undervaluation with $9.27 NZD fair value vs $4.66 current price.

valuation.note: Valuation improved significantly following FY2024 recovery. Stock remains below 3-year highs despite earnings reaching record levels. Deferred tax charge of $12.5m from building depreciation removal was one-time non-cash item.

reports: Seeka Limited Annual Report FY2024 (31 December 2024)
Seeka Limited Condensed Interim Report H1-2025 (30 June 2025)
